promptImprover.title: The Prompt Improver: Because "Make it cool" is a Bad Brief (for AI, Too).
promptImprover.description:
Asking an AI for 'something about AI' is like getting a client brief that just says, 'We want it to go viral.' You'll get something, but it's probably not what you wanted.

This tool is your built-in creative director. It won't let you start with a bad brief. It asks you the annoying-but-necessary questions first: 'Who is this for?' 'What's the tone?' 'What's the one thing you want them to remember?' It turns your vague idea into a brief so sharp, the AI can't help but nail it.

promptImprover.howItWorksDesc: This AI 'brain' powers the Prompt Improver. This System Instruction guides the AI to act as a helpful collaborator.

flowVibe.title: Bonus: Vibe, Flow, Signal Coding
flowVibe.subtitle: This wasn't in the main presentation, but if you're curious about the different ways to structure AI prompts, here's a quick breakdown of the three approaches I use.
flowVibe.intro: Think of it as extra reading if you want to go deeper.

vibe.title: 1. Vibe Coding (The "Director" üé¨)
vibe.description: Fast, creative, and conversational. This is about giving the AI a general direction and iterating based on its output. It's like directing an actor‚Äîyou provide the 'vibe' and see what you get back.
vibe.exampleText: on this page uses Vibe Coding. You give it a rough idea, and it directs the AI to refine it.

flow.title: 2. The "Flow Coding" Confusion
flow.description: The term 'Flow Coding' is ambiguous. It can mean being in 'the zone,' using a Git Flow, building with visual tools like Google Agentspace, or just 'going with the flow.' Because it lacks a clear definition, it's not a useful concept for building reliable AI systems. We need something more precise.
flow.conclusion: Conclusion: 'Signal Coding' is a more useful concept.'

signal.title: 3. Signal Coding (The "Architect" üìê)
signal.description: This is the evolution. Instead of a 'vibe,' you provide a clear, structured 'signal.' Signal Coding is about giving the AI precise, repeatable, and testable instructions to build reliable, production-ready systems. It's the language of AI architects.
signal.workflow: Structured instructions, system prompts, defined inputs/outputs.
signal.goal: Create predictable, scalable, and reliable AI applications.
signal.power: Enables agentic workflows and complex, multi-step tasks.
signal.exampleText: uses Signal Coding. Its two-step process with specific system instructions is a clear 'signal' for a predictable outcome.

howItWasMade.title: A Workflow That Built This Website
howItWasMade.intro1: It started with a problem. I was brainstorming a presentation in my car (using Gemini Live) and had a thought: How many times have you seen a great demo, only to forget it seconds later?
howItWasMade.intro2: It's annoying. You see a practical tool, but the workflow‚Äîthe how and why‚Äîis lost.
howItWasMade.intro3: I decided the presentation shouldn't just show my favorite AI workflows; it should be the workflow. This website is the result. It's a 'Gem' built using the very tools it demonstrates.
howItWasMade.intro4: Here is the 6-step process I used, evolving from a 'vibe' to a 'signal' to build this production-ready site.

step1.title: (The "What?")
step1.problem: What should this site be about? What workflows are actually useful? What's the best way to explain 'Vibe Coding' vs. 'Signal Coding'?
step1.action: I used the Deep Research prompt to analyze my presentation notes, past feedback, and articles on AI development.
step1.outcome: A clear content strategy. The research confirmed the 'Flow Coding' confusion and highlighted the need for a practical, hands-on site focused on 'Signal Coding' (i.e., building reliable, testable AI apps).

step2.title: (The "Brains")
step2.problem: How should the AI tools on this site, like the 'Prompt Improver,' actually behave? I needed to test the logic, fast.
step2.action: This was the 'Vibe Coding' phase. I used AI Studio as a web-based scratchpad. I could write and re-write system prompts, test different inputs, and tweak the AI's 'personality' and logic in seconds without any setup.
step2.outcome: A set of tested, functional, and powerful prompts that form the 'brains' of this site's tools.

step3.title: (The "Look")
step3.problem: The site needed a professional, responsive, and (most importantly) dark-mode-friendly UI, and I didn't want to spend days writing CSS.
step3.action: I wrote a single, detailed design prompt. I described the header, the two-column layout, the card-based design for each 'Gem,' and the color-themed code blocks.
step3.outcome: Stitch generated the entire front-end (HTML, CSS, and React components) in minutes. This wasn't a wireframe; it was 90% of the final code you're seeing now.

step4.title: (The "Glue")
step4.problem: How to connect the 'Brains' (from AI Studio) to the 'Look' (from Stitch) and build a real, testable application?
step4.action: This is where we shift from 'Vibe Coding' (prototyping) to 'Signal Coding' (building). The Gemini CLI is the bridge. It lets me use the exact same AI logic from AI Studio right inside my local terminal and development environment.
step4.outcome: A fully integrated, production-ready React application where the UI and AI logic work together seamlessly.

step5.title: (The "Launch")
step5.problem: How to get this site live and share it with you?
step5.action: I pushed the final application code to a GitHub repository. That repository is connected to Google Cloud Run, which automatically builds and deploys the site, making it live and scalable with a single command.

step6.title: (The "Refinement")
step6.problem: The content was functional, but did it resonate with a Dutch audience? Were the tone, style, and cultural references on point?
step6.action: I created a custom Gem trained on Dutch communication preferences and audience expectations. I fed it all the website copy and asked it to refine the language, tone, and messaging to better connect with this specific audience.
step6.outcome: Culturally-tuned copy that speaks directly to the Dutch market, making the site feel more personal and relevant.
